3""" 

4This module defines base classes for all models. The base class of all 

5models is `~astropy.modeling.Model`. `~astropy.modeling.FittableModel` is 

6the base class for all fittable models. Fittable models can be linear or 

7nonlinear in a regression analysis sense. 

8 

9All models provide a `__call__` method which performs the transformation in 

10a purely mathematical way, i.e. the models are unitless. Model instances can 

11represent either a single model, or a "model set" representing multiple copies 

12of the same type of model, but with potentially different values of the 

13parameters in each model making up the set. 

14""" 

15# pylint: disable=invalid-name, protected-access, redefined-outer-name 

16import abc

18import functools

69def _model_oper(oper, **kwargs): 

70 """ 

71 Returns a function that evaluates a given Python arithmetic operator 

72 between two models. The operator should be given as a string, like ``'+'`` 

73 or ``'**'``. 

74 """ 

75 return lambda left, right: CompoundModel(oper, left, right, **kwargs)

78class ModelDefinitionError(TypeError): 

79 """Used for incorrect models definitions."""

82class _ModelMeta(abc.ABCMeta): 

83 """ 

84 Metaclass for Model. 

85 

86 Currently just handles auto-generating the param_names list based on 

87 Parameter descriptors declared at the class-level of Model subclasses. 

88 """ 

89 

90 _is_dynamic = False 

91 """ 

92 This flag signifies whether this class was created in the "normal" way, 

93 with a class statement in the body of a module, as opposed to a call to 

94 `type` or some other metaclass constructor, such that the resulting class 

95 does not belong to a specific module. This is important for pickling of 

96 dynamic classes. 

97 

98 This flag is always forced to False for new classes, so code that creates 

99 dynamic classes should manually set it to True on those classes when 

100 creating them. 

101 """ 

102 

103 # Default empty dict for _parameters_, which will be empty on model 

104 # classes that don't have any Parameters 

105 

106 def __new__(mcls, name, bases, members, **kwds): 

107 # See the docstring for _is_dynamic above 

108 if "_is_dynamic" not in members: 

109 members["_is_dynamic"] = mcls._is_dynamic 

110 opermethods = [ 

111 ("__add__", _model_oper("+")), 

112 ("__sub__", _model_oper("-")), 

113 ("__mul__", _model_oper("*")), 

114 ("__truediv__", _model_oper("/")), 

115 ("__pow__", _model_oper("**")), 

116 ("__or__", _model_oper("|")), 

117 ("__and__", _model_oper("&")), 

118 ("_fix_inputs", _model_oper("fix_inputs")), 

119 ] 

120 

121 members["_parameters_"] = { 

122 k: v for k, v in members.items() if isinstance(v, Parameter) 

123 } 

124 

125 for opermethod, opercall in opermethods: 

126 members[opermethod] = opercall 

127 cls = super().__new__(mcls, name, bases, members, **kwds) 

128 

129 param_names = list(members["_parameters_"]) 

130 

131 # Need to walk each base MRO to collect all parameter names 

132 for base in bases: 

133 for tbase in base.__mro__: 

134 if issubclass(tbase, Model): 

135 # Preserve order of definitions 

136 param_names = list(tbase._parameters_) + param_names 

137 # Remove duplicates (arising from redefinition in subclass). 

138 param_names = list(dict.fromkeys(param_names)) 

139 if cls._parameters_: 

140 if hasattr(cls, "_param_names"): 

141 # Slight kludge to support compound models, where 

142 # cls.param_names is a property; could be improved with a 

143 # little refactoring but fine for now 

144 cls._param_names = tuple(param_names) 

145 else: 

146 cls.param_names = tuple(param_names) 

147 

148 return cls 

149 

150 def __init__(cls, name, bases, members, **kwds): 

151 super().__init__(name, bases, members, **kwds) 

152 cls._create_inverse_property(members) 

153 cls._create_bounding_box_property(members) 

154 pdict = {} 

155 for base in bases: 

156 for tbase in base.__mro__: 

157 if issubclass(tbase, Model): 

158 for parname, val in cls._parameters_.items(): 

159 pdict[parname] = val 

160 cls._handle_special_methods(members, pdict) 

161 

162 def __repr__(cls): 

163 """ 

164 Custom repr for Model subclasses. 

165 """ 

166 return cls._format_cls_repr() 

167 

168 def _repr_pretty_(cls, p, cycle): 

169 """ 

170 Repr for IPython's pretty printer. 

171 

172 By default IPython "pretty prints" classes, so we need to implement 

173 this so that IPython displays the custom repr for Models. 

174 """ 

175 p.text(repr(cls)) 

176 

177 def __reduce__(cls): 

178 if not cls._is_dynamic: 

179 # Just return a string specifying where the class can be imported 

180 # from 

181 return cls.__name__ 

182 members = dict(cls.__dict__) 

183 # Delete any ABC-related attributes--these will be restored when 

184 # the class is reconstructed: 

185 for key in list(members): 

186 if key.startswith("_abc_"): 

187 del members[key] 

188 

189 # Delete custom __init__ and __call__ if they exist: 

190 for key in ("__init__", "__call__"): 

191 if key in members: 

192 del members[key] 

193 

194 return (type(cls), (cls.__name__, cls.__bases__, members)) 

195 

196 @property 

197 def name(cls): 

198 """ 

199 The name of this model class--equivalent to ``cls.__name__``. 

200 

201 This attribute is provided for symmetry with the `Model.name` attribute 

202 of model instances. 

203 """ 

204 return cls.__name__ 

205 

206 @property 

207 def _is_concrete(cls): 

208 """ 

209 A class-level property that determines whether the class is a concrete 

210 implementation of a Model--i.e. it is not some abstract base class or 

211 internal implementation detail (i.e. begins with '_'). 

212 """ 

213 return not (cls.__name__.startswith("_") or inspect.isabstract(cls)) 

214 

215 def rename(cls, name=None, inputs=None, outputs=None): 

216 """ 

217 Creates a copy of this model class with a new name, inputs or outputs. 

218 

219 The new class is technically a subclass of the original class, so that 

220 instance and type checks will still work. For example:: 

221 

222 >>> from astropy.modeling.models import Rotation2D 

223 >>> SkyRotation = Rotation2D.rename('SkyRotation') 

224 >>> SkyRotation 

225 <class 'astropy.modeling.core.SkyRotation'> 

226 Name: SkyRotation (Rotation2D) 

227 N_inputs: 2 

228 N_outputs: 2 

229 Fittable parameters: ('angle',) 

230 >>> issubclass(SkyRotation, Rotation2D) 

231 True 

232 >>> r = SkyRotation(90) 

233 >>> isinstance(r, Rotation2D) 

234 True 

235 """ 

236 mod = find_current_module(2) 

237 if mod: 

238 modname = mod.__name__ 

239 else: 

240 modname = "__main__" 

241 

242 if name is None: 

243 name = cls.name 

244 if inputs is None: 

245 inputs = cls.inputs 

246 else: 

247 if not isinstance(inputs, tuple): 

248 raise TypeError("Expected 'inputs' to be a tuple of strings.") 

249 elif len(inputs) != len(cls.inputs): 

250 raise ValueError(f"{cls.name} expects {len(cls.inputs)} inputs") 

251 if outputs is None: 

252 outputs = cls.outputs 

253 else: 

254 if not isinstance(outputs, tuple): 

255 raise TypeError("Expected 'outputs' to be a tuple of strings.") 

256 elif len(outputs) != len(cls.outputs): 

257 raise ValueError(f"{cls.name} expects {len(cls.outputs)} outputs") 

258 new_cls = type(name, (cls,), {"inputs": inputs, "outputs": outputs}) 

259 new_cls.__module__ = modname 

260 new_cls.__qualname__ = name 

261 

262 return new_cls 

263 

264 def _create_inverse_property(cls, members): 

265 inverse = members.get("inverse") 

266 if inverse is None or cls.__bases__[0] is object: 

267 # The latter clause is the prevent the below code from running on 

268 # the Model base class, which implements the default getter and 

269 # setter for .inverse 

270 return 

271 

272 if isinstance(inverse, property): 

273 # We allow the @property decorator to be omitted entirely from 

274 # the class definition, though its use should be encouraged for 

275 # clarity 

276 inverse = inverse.fget 

277 

278 # Store the inverse getter internally, then delete the given .inverse 

279 # attribute so that cls.inverse resolves to Model.inverse instead 

280 cls._inverse = inverse 

281 del cls.inverse 

282 

283 def _create_bounding_box_property(cls, members): 

284 """ 

285 Takes any bounding_box defined on a concrete Model subclass (either 

286 as a fixed tuple or a property or method) and wraps it in the generic 

287 getter/setter interface for the bounding_box attribute. 

288 """ 

289 # TODO: Much of this is verbatim from _create_inverse_property--I feel 

290 # like there could be a way to generify properties that work this way, 

291 # but for the time being that would probably only confuse things more. 

292 bounding_box = members.get("bounding_box") 

293 if bounding_box is None or cls.__bases__[0] is object: 

294 return 

295 

296 if isinstance(bounding_box, property): 

297 bounding_box = bounding_box.fget 

298 

299 if not callable(bounding_box): 

300 # See if it's a hard-coded bounding_box (as a sequence) and 

301 # normalize it 

302 try: 

303 bounding_box = ModelBoundingBox.validate( 

304 cls, bounding_box, _preserve_ignore=True 

305 ) 

306 except ValueError as exc: 

307 raise ModelDefinitionError(exc.args[0]) 

308 else: 

309 sig = signature(bounding_box) 

310 # May be a method that only takes 'self' as an argument (like a 

311 # property, but the @property decorator was forgotten) 

312 # 

313 # However, if the method takes additional arguments then this is a 

314 # parameterized bounding box and should be callable 

315 if len(sig.parameters) > 1: 

316 bounding_box = cls._create_bounding_box_subclass(bounding_box, sig) 

317 

318 # See the Model.bounding_box getter definition for how this attribute 

319 # is used 

320 cls._bounding_box = bounding_box 

321 del cls.bounding_box 

322 

323 def _create_bounding_box_subclass(cls, func, sig): 

324 """ 

325 For Models that take optional arguments for defining their bounding 

326 box, we create a subclass of ModelBoundingBox with a ``__call__`` method 

327 that supports those additional arguments. 

328 

329 Takes the function's Signature as an argument since that is already 

330 computed in _create_bounding_box_property, so no need to duplicate that 

331 effort. 

332 """ 

333 # TODO: Might be convenient if calling the bounding box also 

334 # automatically sets the _user_bounding_box. So that 

335 # 

336 # >>> model.bounding_box(arg=1) 

337 # 

338 # in addition to returning the computed bbox, also sets it, so that 

339 # it's a shortcut for 

340 # 

341 # >>> model.bounding_box = model.bounding_box(arg=1) 

342 # 

343 # Not sure if that would be non-obvious / confusing though... 

344 

345 def __call__(self, **kwargs): 

346 return func(self._model, **kwargs) 

347 

348 kwargs = [] 

349 for idx, param in enumerate(sig.parameters.values()): 

350 if idx == 0: 

351 # Presumed to be a 'self' argument 

352 continue 

353 

354 if param.default is param.empty: 

355 raise ModelDefinitionError( 

356 f"The bounding_box method for {cls.name} is not correctly " 

357 "defined: If defined as a method all arguments to that " 

358 "method (besides self) must be keyword arguments with " 

359 "default values that can be used to compute a default " 

360 "bounding box." 

361 ) 

362 

363 kwargs.append((param.name, param.default)) 

364 

365 __call__.__signature__ = sig 

366 

367 return type( 

368 f"{cls.name}ModelBoundingBox", (ModelBoundingBox,), {"__call__": __call__} 

369 ) 

370 

371 def _handle_special_methods(cls, members, pdict): 

372 # Handle init creation from inputs 

373 def update_wrapper(wrapper, cls): 

374 # Set up the new __call__'s metadata attributes as though it were 

375 # manually defined in the class definition 

376 # A bit like functools.update_wrapper but uses the class instead of 

377 # the wrapped function 

378 wrapper.__module__ = cls.__module__ 

379 wrapper.__doc__ = getattr(cls, wrapper.__name__).__doc__ 

380 if hasattr(cls, "__qualname__"): 

381 wrapper.__qualname__ = f"{cls.__qualname__}.{wrapper.__name__}" 

382 

383 if ( 

384 "__call__" not in members 

385 and "n_inputs" in members 

386 and isinstance(members["n_inputs"], int) 

387 and members["n_inputs"] > 0 

388 ): 

389 # Don't create a custom __call__ for classes that already have one 

390 # explicitly defined (this includes the Model base class, and any 

391 # other classes that manually override __call__ 

392 

393 def __call__(self, *inputs, **kwargs): 

394 """Evaluate this model on the supplied inputs.""" 

395 return super(cls, self).__call__(*inputs, **kwargs) 

396 

397 # When called, models can take two optional keyword arguments: 

398 # 

399 # * model_set_axis, which indicates (for multi-dimensional input) 

400 # which axis is used to indicate different models 

401 # 

402 # * equivalencies, a dictionary of equivalencies to be applied to 

403 # the input values, where each key should correspond to one of 

404 # the inputs. 

405 # 

406 # The following code creates the __call__ function with these 

407 # two keyword arguments. 

408 

409 args = ("self",) 

410 kwargs = { 

411 "model_set_axis": None, 

412 "with_bounding_box": False, 

413 "fill_value": np.nan, 

414 "equivalencies": None, 

415 "inputs_map": None, 

416 } 

417 

418 new_call = make_function_with_signature( 

419 __call__, args, kwargs, varargs="inputs", varkwargs="new_inputs" 

420 ) 

421 

422 # The following makes it look like __call__ 

423 # was defined in the class 

424 update_wrapper(new_call, cls) 

425 

426 cls.__call__ = new_call 

427 

428 if ( 

429 "__init__" not in members 

430 and not inspect.isabstract(cls) 

431 and cls._parameters_ 

432 ): 

433 # Build list of all parameters including inherited ones 

434 

435 # If *all* the parameters have default values we can make them 

436 # keyword arguments; otherwise they must all be positional 

437 # arguments 

438 if all(p.default is not None for p in pdict.values()): 

439 args = ("self",) 

440 kwargs = [] 

441 for param_name, param_val in pdict.items(): 

442 default = param_val.default 

443 unit = param_val.unit 

444 # If the unit was specified in the parameter but the 

445 # default is not a Quantity, attach the unit to the 

446 # default. 

447 if unit is not None: 

448 default = Quantity(default, unit, copy=False, subok=True) 

449 kwargs.append((param_name, default)) 

450 else: 

451 args = ("self",) + tuple(pdict.keys()) 

452 kwargs = {} 

453 

454 def __init__(self, *params, **kwargs): 

455 return super(cls, self).__init__(*params, **kwargs) 

456 

457 new_init = make_function_with_signature( 

458 __init__, args, kwargs, varkwargs="kwargs" 

459 ) 

460 update_wrapper(new_init, cls) 

461 cls.__init__ = new_init 

462

475 def _format_cls_repr(cls, keywords=[]): 

476 """ 

477 Internal implementation of ``__repr__``. 

478 

479 This is separated out for ease of use by subclasses that wish to 

480 override the default ``__repr__`` while keeping the same basic 

481 formatting. 

482 """ 

483 # For the sake of familiarity start the output with the standard class 

484 # __repr__ 

485 parts = [super().__repr__()] 

486 

487 if not cls._is_concrete: 

488 return parts[0] 

489 

490 def format_inheritance(cls): 

491 bases = [] 

492 for base in cls.mro()[1:]: 

493 if not issubclass(base, Model): 

494 continue 

495 elif inspect.isabstract(base) or base.__name__.startswith("_"): 

496 break 

497 bases.append(base.name) 

498 if bases: 

499 return f"{cls.name} ({' -> '.join(bases)})" 

500 return cls.name 

501 

502 try: 

503 default_keywords = [ 

504 ("Name", format_inheritance(cls)), 

505 ("N_inputs", cls.n_inputs), 

506 ("N_outputs", cls.n_outputs), 

507 ] 

508 

509 if cls.param_names: 

510 default_keywords.append(("Fittable parameters", cls.param_names)) 

511 

512 for keyword, value in default_keywords + keywords: 

513 if value is not None: 

514 parts.append(f"{keyword}: {value}") 

515 

516 return "\n".join(parts) 

517 except Exception: 

518 # If any of the above formatting fails fall back on the basic repr 

519 # (this is particularly useful in debugging) 

520 return parts[0]

523class Model(metaclass=_ModelMeta): 

524 """ 

525 Base class for all models. 

526 

527 This is an abstract class and should not be instantiated directly. 

528 

529 The following initialization arguments apply to the majority of Model 

530 subclasses by default (exceptions include specialized utility models 

531 like `~astropy.modeling.mappings.Mapping`). Parametric models take all 

532 their parameters as arguments, followed by any of the following optional 

533 keyword arguments: 

534 

535 Parameters 

536 ---------- 

537 name : str, optional 

538 A human-friendly name associated with this model instance 

539 (particularly useful for identifying the individual components of a 

540 compound model). 

541 

542 meta : dict, optional 

543 An optional dict of user-defined metadata to attach to this model. 

544 How this is used and interpreted is up to the user or individual use 

545 case. 

546 

547 n_models : int, optional 

548 If given an integer greater than 1, a *model set* is instantiated 

549 instead of a single model. This affects how the parameter arguments 

550 are interpreted. In this case each parameter must be given as a list 

551 or array--elements of this array are taken along the first axis (or 

552 ``model_set_axis`` if specified), such that the Nth element is the 

553 value of that parameter for the Nth model in the set. 

554 

555 See the section on model sets in the documentation for more details. 

556 

557 model_set_axis : int, optional 

558 This argument only applies when creating a model set (i.e. ``n_models > 

559 1``). It changes how parameter values are interpreted. Normally the 

560 first axis of each input parameter array (properly the 0th axis) is 

561 taken as the axis corresponding to the model sets. However, any axis 

562 of an input array may be taken as this "model set axis". This accepts 

563 negative integers as well--for example use ``model_set_axis=-1`` if the 

564 last (most rapidly changing) axis should be associated with the model 

565 sets. Also, ``model_set_axis=False`` can be used to tell that a given 

566 input should be used to evaluate all the models in the model set. 

567 

568 fixed : dict, optional 

569 Dictionary ``{parameter_name: bool}`` setting the fixed constraint 

570 for one or more parameters. `True` means the parameter is held fixed 

571 during fitting and is prevented from updates once an instance of the 

572 model has been created. 

573 

574 Alternatively the `~astropy.modeling.Parameter.fixed` property of a 

575 parameter may be used to lock or unlock individual parameters. 

576 

577 tied : dict, optional 

578 Dictionary ``{parameter_name: callable}`` of parameters which are 

579 linked to some other parameter. The dictionary values are callables 

580 providing the linking relationship. 

581 

582 Alternatively the `~astropy.modeling.Parameter.tied` property of a 

583 parameter may be used to set the ``tied`` constraint on individual 

584 parameters. 

585 

586 bounds : dict, optional 

587 A dictionary ``{parameter_name: value}`` of lower and upper bounds of 

588 parameters. Keys are parameter names. Values are a list or a tuple 

589 of length 2 giving the desired range for the parameter. 

590 

591 Alternatively the `~astropy.modeling.Parameter.min` and 

592 `~astropy.modeling.Parameter.max` or 

593 ~astropy.modeling.Parameter.bounds` properties of a parameter may be 

594 used to set bounds on individual parameters. 

595 

596 eqcons : list, optional 

597 List of functions of length n such that ``eqcons[j](x0, *args) == 0.0`` 

598 in a successfully optimized problem. 

599 

600 ineqcons : list, optional 

601 List of functions of length n such that ``ieqcons[j](x0, *args) >= 

602 0.0`` is a successfully optimized problem. 

603 

604 Examples 

605 -------- 

606 >>> from astropy.modeling import models 

607 >>> def tie_center(model): 

608 ... mean = 50 * model.stddev 

609 ... return mean 

610 >>> tied_parameters = {'mean': tie_center} 

611 

612 Specify that ``'mean'`` is a tied parameter in one of two ways: 

613 

614 >>> g1 = models.Gaussian1D(amplitude=10, mean=5, stddev=.3, 

615 ... tied=tied_parameters) 

616 

617 or 

618 

619 >>> g1 = models.Gaussian1D(amplitude=10, mean=5, stddev=.3) 

620 >>> g1.mean.tied 

621 False 

622 >>> g1.mean.tied = tie_center 

623 >>> g1.mean.tied 

624 <function tie_center at 0x...> 

625 

626 Fixed parameters: 

627 

628 >>> g1 = models.Gaussian1D(amplitude=10, mean=5, stddev=.3, 

629 ... fixed={'stddev': True}) 

630 >>> g1.stddev.fixed 

631 True 

632 

633 or 

634 

635 >>> g1 = models.Gaussian1D(amplitude=10, mean=5, stddev=.3) 

636 >>> g1.stddev.fixed 

637 False 

638 >>> g1.stddev.fixed = True 

639 >>> g1.stddev.fixed 

640 True 

641 """ 

642 

643 parameter_constraints = Parameter.constraints 

644 """ 

645 Primarily for informational purposes, these are the types of constraints 

646 that can be set on a model's parameters. 

647 """ 

648 

649 model_constraints = ("eqcons", "ineqcons") 

650 """ 

651 Primarily for informational purposes, these are the types of constraints 

652 that constrain model evaluation. 

653 """ 

654 

655 param_names = () 

656 """ 

657 Names of the parameters that describe models of this type. 

658 

659 The parameters in this tuple are in the same order they should be passed in 

660 when initializing a model of a specific type. Some types of models, such 

661 as polynomial models, have a different number of parameters depending on 

662 some other property of the model, such as the degree. 

663 

664 When defining a custom model class the value of this attribute is 

665 automatically set by the `~astropy.modeling.Parameter` attributes defined 

666 in the class body. 

667 """ 

668 

669 n_inputs = 0 

670 """The number of inputs.""" 

671 n_outputs = 0 

672 """ The number of outputs.""" 

673 

674 standard_broadcasting = True 

675 fittable = False 

676 linear = True 

677 _separable = None 

678 """ A boolean flag to indicate whether a model is separable.""" 

679 meta = metadata.MetaData() 

680 """A dict-like object to store optional information.""" 

681 

682 # By default models either use their own inverse property or have no 

683 # inverse at all, but users may also assign a custom inverse to a model, 

684 # optionally; in that case it is of course up to the user to determine 

685 # whether their inverse is *actually* an inverse to the model they assign 

686 # it to. 

687 _inverse = None 

688 _user_inverse = None 

689 

690 _bounding_box = None 

691 _user_bounding_box = None 

692 

693 _has_inverse_bounding_box = False 

694 

695 # Default n_models attribute, so that __len__ is still defined even when a 

696 # model hasn't completed initialization yet 

697 _n_models = 1 

698 

699 # New classes can set this as a boolean value. 

700 # It is converted to a dictionary mapping input name to a boolean value. 

701 _input_units_strict = False 

702 

703 # Allow dimensionless input (and corresponding output). If this is True, 

704 # input values to evaluate will gain the units specified in input_units. If 

705 # this is a dictionary then it should map input name to a bool to allow 

706 # dimensionless numbers for that input. 

707 # Only has an effect if input_units is defined. 

708 _input_units_allow_dimensionless = False 

709 

710 # Default equivalencies to apply to input values. If set, this should be a 

711 # dictionary where each key is a string that corresponds to one of the 

712 # model inputs. Only has an effect if input_units is defined. 

713 input_units_equivalencies = None 

714 

715 # Covariance matrix can be set by fitter if available. 

716 # If cov_matrix is available, then std will set as well 

717 _cov_matrix = None 

718 _stds = None 

719 

720 def __init_subclass__(cls, **kwargs): 

721 super().__init_subclass__() 

722 

723 def __init__(self, *args, meta=None, name=None, **kwargs): 

724 super().__init__() 

725 self._default_inputs_outputs() 

726 if meta is not None: 

727 self.meta = meta 

728 self._name = name 

729 # add parameters to instance level by walking MRO list 

730 mro = self.__class__.__mro__ 

731 for cls in mro: 

732 if issubclass(cls, Model): 

733 for parname, val in cls._parameters_.items(): 

734 newpar = copy.deepcopy(val) 

735 newpar.model = self 

736 if parname not in self.__dict__: 

737 self.__dict__[parname] = newpar 

738 

739 self._initialize_constraints(kwargs) 

740 kwargs = self._initialize_setters(kwargs) 

741 # Remaining keyword args are either parameter values or invalid 

742 # Parameter values must be passed in as keyword arguments in order to 

743 # distinguish them 

744 self._initialize_parameters(args, kwargs) 

745 self._initialize_slices() 

746 self._initialize_unit_support() 

747 

748 def _default_inputs_outputs(self): 

749 if self.n_inputs == 1 and self.n_outputs == 1: 

750 self._inputs = ("x",) 

751 self._outputs = ("y",) 

752 elif self.n_inputs == 2 and self.n_outputs == 1: 

753 self._inputs = ("x", "y") 

754 self._outputs = ("z",) 

755 else: 

756 try: 

757 self._inputs = tuple("x" + str(idx) for idx in range(self.n_inputs)) 

758 self._outputs = tuple("x" + str(idx) for idx in range(self.n_outputs)) 

759 except TypeError: 

760 # self.n_inputs and self.n_outputs are properties 

761 # This is the case when subclasses of Model do not define 

762 # ``n_inputs``, ``n_outputs``, ``inputs`` or ``outputs``. 

763 self._inputs = () 

764 self._outputs = () 

765 

766 def _initialize_setters(self, kwargs): 

767 """ 

768 This exists to inject defaults for settable properties for models 

769 originating from `custom_model`. 

770 """ 

771 if hasattr(self, "_settable_properties"): 

772 setters = { 

773 name: kwargs.pop(name, default) 

774 for name, default in self._settable_properties.items() 

775 } 

776 for name, value in setters.items(): 

777 setattr(self, name, value) 

778 

779 return kwargs 

780 

781 @property 

782 def inputs(self): 

783 return self._inputs 

784 

785 @inputs.setter 

786 def inputs(self, val): 

787 if len(val) != self.n_inputs: 

788 raise ValueError( 

789 f"Expected {self.n_inputs} number of inputs, got {len(val)}." 

790 ) 

791 self._inputs = val 

792 self._initialize_unit_support() 

793 

794 @property 

795 def outputs(self): 

796 return self._outputs 

797 

798 @outputs.setter 

799 def outputs(self, val): 

800 if len(val) != self.n_outputs: 

801 raise ValueError( 

802 f"Expected {self.n_outputs} number of outputs, got {len(val)}." 

803 ) 

804 self._outputs = val 

805 

806 @property 

807 def n_inputs(self): 

808 # TODO: remove the code in the ``if`` block when support 

809 # for models with ``inputs`` as class variables is removed. 

810 if hasattr(self.__class__, "n_inputs") and isinstance( 

811 self.__class__.n_inputs, property 

812 ): 

813 try: 

814 return len(self.__class__.inputs) 

815 except TypeError: 

816 try: 

817 return len(self.inputs) 

818 except AttributeError: 

819 return 0 

820 

821 return self.__class__.n_inputs 

822 

823 @property 

824 def n_outputs(self): 

825 # TODO: remove the code in the ``if`` block when support 

826 # for models with ``outputs`` as class variables is removed. 

827 if hasattr(self.__class__, "n_outputs") and isinstance( 

828 self.__class__.n_outputs, property 

829 ): 

830 try: 

831 return len(self.__class__.outputs) 

832 except TypeError: 

833 try: 

834 return len(self.outputs) 

835 except AttributeError: 

836 return 0 

837 

838 return self.__class__.n_outputs

840 def _calculate_separability_matrix(self): 

841 """ 

842 This is a hook which customises the behavior of modeling.separable. 

843 

844 This allows complex subclasses to customise the separability matrix. 

845 If it returns `NotImplemented` the default behavior is used. 

846 """ 

847 return NotImplemented 

848 

849 def _initialize_unit_support(self): 

850 """ 

851 Convert self._input_units_strict and 

852 self.input_units_allow_dimensionless to dictionaries 

853 mapping input name to a boolean value. 

854 """ 

855 if isinstance(self._input_units_strict, bool): 

856 self._input_units_strict = { 

857 key: self._input_units_strict for key in self.inputs 

858 } 

859 

860 if isinstance(self._input_units_allow_dimensionless, bool): 

861 self._input_units_allow_dimensionless = { 

862 key: self._input_units_allow_dimensionless for key in self.inputs 

863 } 

864 

865 @property 

866 def input_units_strict(self): 

867 """ 

868 Enforce strict units on inputs to evaluate. If this is set to True, 

869 input values to evaluate will be in the exact units specified by 

870 input_units. If the input quantities are convertible to input_units, 

871 they are converted. If this is a dictionary then it should map input 

872 name to a bool to set strict input units for that parameter. 

873 """ 

874 val = self._input_units_strict 

875 if isinstance(val, bool): 

876 return {key: val for key in self.inputs} 

877 return dict(zip(self.inputs, val.values())) 

878 

879 @property 

880 def input_units_allow_dimensionless(self): 

881 """ 

882 Allow dimensionless input (and corresponding output). If this is True, 

883 input values to evaluate will gain the units specified in input_units. If 

884 this is a dictionary then it should map input name to a bool to allow 

885 dimensionless numbers for that input. 

886 Only has an effect if input_units is defined. 

887 """ 

888 val = self._input_units_allow_dimensionless 

889 if isinstance(val, bool): 

890 return {key: val for key in self.inputs} 

891 return dict(zip(self.inputs, val.values())) 

892 

893 @property 

894 def uses_quantity(self): 

895 """ 

896 True if this model has been created with `~astropy.units.Quantity` 

897 objects or if there are no parameters. 

898 

899 This can be used to determine if this model should be evaluated with 

900 `~astropy.units.Quantity` or regular floats. 

901 """ 

902 pisq = [isinstance(p, Quantity) for p in self._param_sets(units=True)] 

903 return (len(pisq) == 0) or any(pisq) 

904 

905 def __repr__(self): 

906 return self._format_repr() 

907 

908 def __str__(self): 

909 return self._format_str() 

910 

911 def __len__(self): 

912 return self._n_models 

913 

914 @staticmethod 

915 def _strip_ones(intup): 

916 return tuple(item for item in intup if item != 1) 

917 

918 def __setattr__(self, attr, value): 

919 if isinstance(self, CompoundModel): 

920 param_names = self._param_names 

921 param_names = self.param_names 

922 

923 if param_names is not None and attr in self.param_names: 

924 param = self.__dict__[attr] 

925 value = _tofloat(value) 

926 if param._validator is not None: 

927 param._validator(self, value) 

928 # check consistency with previous shape and size 

929 eshape = self._param_metrics[attr]["shape"] 

930 if eshape == (): 

931 eshape = (1,) 

932 vshape = np.array(value).shape 

933 if vshape == (): 

934 vshape = (1,) 

935 esize = self._param_metrics[attr]["size"] 

936 if np.size(value) != esize or self._strip_ones(vshape) != self._strip_ones( 

937 eshape 

938 ): 

939 raise InputParameterError( 

940 f"Value for parameter {attr} does not match shape or size\nexpected" 

941 f" by model ({vshape}, {np.size(value)}) vs ({eshape}, {esize})" 

942 ) 

943 if param.unit is None: 

944 if isinstance(value, Quantity): 

945 param._unit = value.unit 

946 param.value = value.value 

947 else: 

948 param.value = value 

949 else: 

950 if not isinstance(value, Quantity): 

951 raise UnitsError( 

952 f"The '{param.name}' parameter should be given as a" 

953 " Quantity because it was originally " 

954 "initialized as a Quantity" 

955 ) 

956 param._unit = value.unit 

957 param.value = value.value 

958 else: 

959 if attr in ["fittable", "linear"]: 

960 self.__dict__[attr] = value 

961 else: 

962 super().__setattr__(attr, value) 

963 

964 def _pre_evaluate(self, *args, **kwargs): 

965 """ 

966 Model specific input setup that needs to occur prior to model evaluation. 

967 """ 

968 # Broadcast inputs into common size 

969 inputs, broadcasted_shapes = self.prepare_inputs(*args, **kwargs) 

970 

971 # Setup actual model evaluation method 

972 parameters = self._param_sets(raw=True, units=True) 

973 

974 def evaluate(_inputs): 

975 return self.evaluate(*chain(_inputs, parameters)) 

976 

977 return evaluate, inputs, broadcasted_shapes, kwargs 

978 

979 def get_bounding_box(self, with_bbox=True): 

980 """ 

981 Return the ``bounding_box`` of a model if it exists or ``None`` 

982 otherwise. 

983 

984 Parameters 

985 ---------- 

986 with_bbox : 

987 The value of the ``with_bounding_box`` keyword argument 

988 when calling the model. Default is `True` for usage when 

989 looking up the model's ``bounding_box`` without risk of error. 

990 """ 

991 bbox = None 

992 

993 if not isinstance(with_bbox, bool) or with_bbox: 

994 try: 

995 bbox = self.bounding_box 

996 except NotImplementedError: 

997 pass 

998 

999 if isinstance(bbox, CompoundBoundingBox) and not isinstance( 

1000 with_bbox, bool 

1001 ): 

1002 bbox = bbox[with_bbox] 

1003 

1004 return bbox 

1005 

1006 @property 

1007 def _argnames(self): 

1008 """The inputs used to determine input_shape for bounding_box evaluation.""" 

1009 return self.inputs 

1010 

1011 def _validate_input_shape( 

1012 self, _input, idx, argnames, model_set_axis, check_model_set_axis 

1013 ): 

1014 """Perform basic validation of a single model input's shape. 

1015 

1016 The shape has the minimum dimensions for the given model_set_axis. 

1017 

1018 Returns the shape of the input if validation succeeds. 

1019 """ 

1020 input_shape = np.shape(_input) 

1021 # Ensure that the input's model_set_axis matches the model's 

1022 # n_models 

1023 if input_shape and check_model_set_axis: 

1024 # Note: Scalar inputs *only* get a pass on this 

1025 if len(input_shape) < model_set_axis + 1: 

1026 raise ValueError( 

1027 f"For model_set_axis={model_set_axis}, all inputs must be at " 

1028 f"least {model_set_axis + 1}-dimensional." 

1029 ) 

1030 if input_shape[model_set_axis] != self._n_models: 

1031 try: 

1032 argname = argnames[idx] 

1033 except IndexError: 

1034 # the case of model.inputs = () 

1035 argname = str(idx) 

1036 

1037 raise ValueError( 

1038 f"Input argument '{argname}' does not have the correct dimensions" 

1039 f" in model_set_axis={model_set_axis} for a model set with" 

1040 f" n_models={self._n_models}." 

1041 ) 

1042 

1043 return input_shape 

1044 

1045 def _validate_input_shapes(self, inputs, argnames, model_set_axis): 

1046 """ 

1047 Perform basic validation of model inputs 

1048 --that they are mutually broadcastable and that they have 

1049 the minimum dimensions for the given model_set_axis. 

1050 

1051 If validation succeeds, returns the total shape that will result from 

1052 broadcasting the input arrays with each other. 

1053 """ 

1054 check_model_set_axis = self._n_models > 1 and model_set_axis is not False 

1055 

1056 all_shapes = [] 

1057 for idx, _input in enumerate(inputs): 

1058 all_shapes.append( 

1059 self._validate_input_shape( 

1060 _input, idx, argnames, model_set_axis, check_model_set_axis 

1061 ) 

1062 ) 

1063 

1064 input_shape = check_broadcast(*all_shapes) 

1065 if input_shape is None: 

1066 raise ValueError( 

1067 "All inputs must have identical shapes or must be scalars." 

1068 ) 

1069 

1070 return input_shape 

1071 

1072 def input_shape(self, inputs): 

1073 """Get input shape for bounding_box evaluation.""" 

1074 return self._validate_input_shapes(inputs, self._argnames, self.model_set_axis) 

1075 

1076 def _generic_evaluate(self, evaluate, _inputs, fill_value, with_bbox): 

1077 """Generic model evaluation routine. 

1078 

1079 Selects and evaluates model with or without bounding_box enforcement. 

1080 """ 

1081 # Evaluate the model using the prepared evaluation method either 

1082 # enforcing the bounding_box or not. 

1083 bbox = self.get_bounding_box(with_bbox) 

1084 if (not isinstance(with_bbox, bool) or with_bbox) and bbox is not None: 

1085 outputs = bbox.evaluate(evaluate, _inputs, fill_value) 

1086 else: 

1087 outputs = evaluate(_inputs) 

1088 return outputs 

1089 

1090 def _post_evaluate(self, inputs, outputs, broadcasted_shapes, with_bbox, **kwargs): 

1091 """ 

1092 Model specific post evaluation processing of outputs. 

1093 """ 

1094 if self.get_bounding_box(with_bbox) is None and self.n_outputs == 1: 

1095 outputs = (outputs,) 

1096 

1097 outputs = self.prepare_outputs(broadcasted_shapes, *outputs, **kwargs) 

1098 outputs = self._process_output_units(inputs, outputs) 

1099 

1100 if self.n_outputs == 1: 

1101 return outputs[0] 

1102 return outputs 

1103 

1104 @property 

1105 def bbox_with_units(self): 

1106 return not isinstance(self, CompoundModel) 

1107 

1108 def __call__(self, *args, **kwargs): 

1109 """ 

1110 Evaluate this model using the given input(s) and the parameter values 

1111 that were specified when the model was instantiated. 

1112 """ 

1113 # Turn any keyword arguments into positional arguments. 

1114 args, kwargs = self._get_renamed_inputs_as_positional(*args, **kwargs) 

1115 

1116 # Read model evaluation related parameters 

1117 with_bbox = kwargs.pop("with_bounding_box", False) 

1118 fill_value = kwargs.pop("fill_value", np.nan) 

1119 

1120 # prepare for model evaluation (overridden in CompoundModel) 

1121 evaluate, inputs, broadcasted_shapes, kwargs = self._pre_evaluate( 

1122 *args, **kwargs 

1123 ) 

1124 

1125 outputs = self._generic_evaluate(evaluate, inputs, fill_value, with_bbox) 

1126 

1127 # post-process evaluation results (overridden in CompoundModel) 

1128 return self._post_evaluate( 

1129 inputs, outputs, broadcasted_shapes, with_bbox, **kwargs 

1130 ) 

1131 

1132 def _get_renamed_inputs_as_positional(self, *args, **kwargs): 

1133 def _keyword2positional(kwargs): 

1134 # Inputs were passed as keyword (not positional) arguments. 

1135 # Because the signature of the ``__call__`` is defined at 

1136 # the class level, the name of the inputs cannot be changed at 

1137 # the instance level and the old names are always present in the 

1138 # signature of the method. In order to use the new names of the 

1139 # inputs, the old names are taken out of ``kwargs``, the input 

1140 # values are sorted in the order of self.inputs and passed as 

1141 # positional arguments to ``__call__``. 

1142 

1143 # These are the keys that are always present as keyword arguments. 

1144 keys = [ 

1145 "model_set_axis", 

1146 "with_bounding_box", 

1147 "fill_value", 

1148 "equivalencies", 

1149 "inputs_map", 

1150 ] 

1151 

1152 new_inputs = {} 

1153 # kwargs contain the names of the new inputs + ``keys`` 

1154 allkeys = list(kwargs.keys()) 

1155 # Remove the names of the new inputs from kwargs and save them 

1156 # to a dict ``new_inputs``. 

1157 for key in allkeys: 

1158 if key not in keys: 

1159 new_inputs[key] = kwargs[key] 

1160 del kwargs[key] 

1161 return new_inputs, kwargs 

1162 

1163 n_args = len(args) 

1164 

1165 new_inputs, kwargs = _keyword2positional(kwargs) 

1166 n_all_args = n_args + len(new_inputs) 

1167 

1168 if n_all_args < self.n_inputs: 

1169 raise ValueError( 

1170 f"Missing input arguments - expected {self.n_inputs}, got {n_all_args}" 

1171 ) 

1172 elif n_all_args > self.n_inputs: 

1173 raise ValueError( 

1174 f"Too many input arguments - expected {self.n_inputs}, got {n_all_args}" 

1175 ) 

1176 if n_args == 0: 

1177 # Create positional arguments from the keyword arguments in ``new_inputs``. 

1178 new_args = [] 

1179 for k in self.inputs: 

1180 new_args.append(new_inputs[k]) 

1181 elif n_args != self.n_inputs: 

1182 # Some inputs are passed as positional, others as keyword arguments. 

1183 args = list(args) 

1184 

1185 # Create positional arguments from the keyword arguments in ``new_inputs``. 

1186 new_args = [] 

1187 for k in self.inputs: 

1188 if k in new_inputs: 

1189 new_args.append(new_inputs[k]) 

1190 else: 

1191 new_args.append(args[0]) 

1192 del args[0] 

1193 else: 

1194 new_args = args 

1195 return new_args, kwargs

1220 @property

1222 """ 

1223 Return parameters as a pset. 

1224 

1225 This is a list with one item per parameter set, which is an array of 

1226 that parameter's values across all parameter sets, with the last axis 

1227 associated with the parameter set. 

1228 """

1230 

1231 @property 

1232 def parameters(self): 

1233 """ 

1234 A flattened array of all parameter values in all parameter sets. 

1235 

1236 Fittable parameters maintain this list and fitters modify it. 

1237 """ 

1238 # Currently the sequence of a model's parameters must be contiguous 

1239 # within the _parameters array (which may be a view of a larger array, 

1240 # for example when taking a sub-expression of a compound model), so 

1241 # the assumption here is reliable: 

1242 if not self.param_names: 

1243 # Trivial, but not unheard of 

1244 return self._parameters 

1245 

1246 self._parameters_to_array() 

1247 start = self._param_metrics[self.param_names[0]]["slice"].start 

1248 stop = self._param_metrics[self.param_names[-1]]["slice"].stop 

1249 

1250 return self._parameters[start:stop] 

1251 

1252 @parameters.setter 

1253 def parameters(self, value): 

1254 """ 

1255 Assigning to this attribute updates the parameters array rather than 

1256 replacing it. 

1257 """ 

1258 if not self.param_names: 

1259 return 

1260 

1261 start = self._param_metrics[self.param_names[0]]["slice"].start 

1262 stop = self._param_metrics[self.param_names[-1]]["slice"].stop 

1263 

1264 try: 

1265 value = np.array(value).flatten() 

1266 self._parameters[start:stop] = value 

1267 except ValueError as e: 

1268 raise InputParameterError( 

1269 "Input parameter values not compatible with the model " 

1270 f"parameters array: {e!r}" 

1271 ) 

1272 self._array_to_parameters() 

1273

1278 automatically check the constituent models current values. It defaults to True 

1279 on creation of a model, but for fitting purposes it should be set to False 

1280 for performance reasons.

1282 if not hasattr(self, "_sync_constraints"): 

1283 self._sync_constraints = True 

1284 return self._sync_constraints

1290 self._sync_constraints = value

1341 

1342 @property 

1343 def inverse(self): 

1344 """ 

1345 Returns a new `~astropy.modeling.Model` instance which performs the 

1346 inverse transform, if an analytic inverse is defined for this model. 

1347 

1348 Even on models that don't have an inverse defined, this property can be 

1349 set with a manually-defined inverse, such a pre-computed or 

1350 experimentally determined inverse (often given as a 

1351 `~astropy.modeling.polynomial.PolynomialModel`, but not by 

1352 requirement). 

1353 

1354 A custom inverse can be deleted with ``del model.inverse``. In this 

1355 case the model's inverse is reset to its default, if a default exists 

1356 (otherwise the default is to raise `NotImplementedError`). 

1357 

1358 Note to authors of `~astropy.modeling.Model` subclasses: To define an 

1359 inverse for a model simply override this property to return the 

1360 appropriate model representing the inverse. The machinery that will 

1361 make the inverse manually-overridable is added automatically by the 

1362 base class. 

1363 """ 

1364 if self._user_inverse is not None: 

1365 return self._user_inverse 

1366 elif self._inverse is not None: 

1367 result = self._inverse() 

1368 if result is not NotImplemented: 

1369 if not self._has_inverse_bounding_box: 

1370 result.bounding_box = None 

1371 return result 

1372 

1373 raise NotImplementedError( 

1374 "No analytical or user-supplied inverse transform " 

1375 "has been implemented for this model." 

1376 ) 

1377 

1378 @inverse.setter 

1379 def inverse(self, value): 

1380 if not isinstance(value, (Model, type(None))): 

1381 raise ValueError( 

1382 "The ``inverse`` attribute may be assigned a `Model` " 

1383 "instance or `None` (where `None` explicitly forces the " 

1384 "model to have no inverse." 

1385 ) 

1386 

1387 self._user_inverse = value 

1388 

1389 @inverse.deleter 

1390 def inverse(self): 

1391 """ 

1392 Resets the model's inverse to its default (if one exists, otherwise 

1393 the model will have no inverse). 

1394 """ 

1395 try: 

1396 del self._user_inverse 

1397 except AttributeError: 

1398 pass 

1399 

1400 @property 

1401 def has_user_inverse(self): 

1402 """ 

1403 A flag indicating whether or not a custom inverse model has been 

1404 assigned to this model by a user, via assignment to ``model.inverse``. 

1405 """ 

1406 return self._user_inverse is not None 

1407 

1408 @property 

1409 def bounding_box(self): 

1410 r""" 

1411 A `tuple` of length `n_inputs` defining the bounding box limits, or 

1412 raise `NotImplementedError` for no bounding_box. 

1413 

1414 The default limits are given by a ``bounding_box`` property or method 

1415 defined in the class body of a specific model. If not defined then 

1416 this property just raises `NotImplementedError` by default (but may be 

1417 assigned a custom value by a user). ``bounding_box`` can be set 

1418 manually to an array-like object of shape ``(model.n_inputs, 2)``. For 

1419 further usage, see :ref:`astropy:bounding-boxes` 

1420 

1421 The limits are ordered according to the `numpy` ``'C'`` indexing 

1422 convention, and are the reverse of the model input order, 

1423 e.g. for inputs ``('x', 'y', 'z')``, ``bounding_box`` is defined: 

1424 

1425 * for 1D: ``(x_low, x_high)`` 

1426 * for 2D: ``((y_low, y_high), (x_low, x_high))`` 

1427 * for 3D: ``((z_low, z_high), (y_low, y_high), (x_low, x_high))`` 

1428 

1429 Examples 

1430 -------- 

1431 Setting the ``bounding_box`` limits for a 1D and 2D model: 

1432 

1433 >>> from astropy.modeling.models import Gaussian1D, Gaussian2D 

1434 >>> model_1d = Gaussian1D() 

1435 >>> model_2d = Gaussian2D(x_stddev=1, y_stddev=1) 

1436 >>> model_1d.bounding_box = (-5, 5) 

1437 >>> model_2d.bounding_box = ((-6, 6), (-5, 5)) 

1438 

1439 Setting the bounding_box limits for a user-defined 3D `custom_model`: 

1440 

1441 >>> from astropy.modeling.models import custom_model 

1442 >>> def const3d(x, y, z, amp=1): 

1443 ... return amp 

1444 ... 

1445 >>> Const3D = custom_model(const3d) 

1446 >>> model_3d = Const3D() 

1447 >>> model_3d.bounding_box = ((-6, 6), (-5, 5), (-4, 4)) 

1448 

1449 To reset ``bounding_box`` to its default limits just delete the 

1450 user-defined value--this will reset it back to the default defined 

1451 on the class: 

1452 

1453 >>> del model_1d.bounding_box 

1454 

1455 To disable the bounding box entirely (including the default), 

1456 set ``bounding_box`` to `None`: 

1457 

1458 >>> model_1d.bounding_box = None 

1459 >>> model_1d.bounding_box # doctest: +IGNORE_EXCEPTION_DETAIL 

1460 Traceback (most recent call last): 

1461 NotImplementedError: No bounding box is defined for this model 

1462 (note: the bounding box was explicitly disabled for this model; 

1463 use `del model.bounding_box` to restore the default bounding box, 

1464 if one is defined for this model). 

1465 """ 

1466 if self._user_bounding_box is not None: 

1467 if self._user_bounding_box is NotImplemented: 

1468 raise NotImplementedError( 

1469 "No bounding box is defined for this model (note: the " 

1470 "bounding box was explicitly disabled for this model; " 

1471 "use `del model.bounding_box` to restore the default " 

1472 "bounding box, if one is defined for this model)." 

1473 ) 

1474 return self._user_bounding_box 

1475 elif self._bounding_box is None: 

1476 raise NotImplementedError("No bounding box is defined for this model.") 

1477 elif isinstance(self._bounding_box, ModelBoundingBox): 

1478 # This typically implies a hard-coded bounding box. This will 

1479 # probably be rare, but it is an option 

1480 return self._bounding_box 

1481 elif isinstance(self._bounding_box, types.MethodType): 

1482 return ModelBoundingBox.validate(self, self._bounding_box()) 

1483 else: 

1484 # The only other allowed possibility is that it's a ModelBoundingBox 

1485 # subclass, so we call it with its default arguments and return an 

1486 # instance of it (that can be called to recompute the bounding box 

1487 # with any optional parameters) 

1488 # (In other words, in this case self._bounding_box is a *class*) 

1489 bounding_box = self._bounding_box((), model=self)() 

1490 return self._bounding_box(bounding_box, model=self) 

1491 

1492 @bounding_box.setter 

1493 def bounding_box(self, bounding_box): 

1494 """ 

1495 Assigns the bounding box limits. 

1496 """ 

1497 if bounding_box is None: 

1498 cls = None 

1499 # We use this to explicitly set an unimplemented bounding box (as 

1500 # opposed to no user bounding box defined) 

1501 bounding_box = NotImplemented 

1502 elif isinstance(bounding_box, (CompoundBoundingBox, dict)): 

1503 cls = CompoundBoundingBox 

1504 elif isinstance(self._bounding_box, type) and issubclass( 

1505 self._bounding_box, ModelBoundingBox 

1506 ): 

1507 cls = self._bounding_box 

1508 else: 

1509 cls = ModelBoundingBox 

1510 

1511 if cls is not None: 

1512 try: 

1513 bounding_box = cls.validate(self, bounding_box, _preserve_ignore=True) 

1514 except ValueError as exc: 

1515 raise ValueError(exc.args[0]) 

1516 

1517 self._user_bounding_box = bounding_box 

1518 

1519 def set_slice_args(self, *args): 

1520 if isinstance(self._user_bounding_box, CompoundBoundingBox): 

1521 self._user_bounding_box.slice_args = args 

1522 else: 

1523 raise RuntimeError("The bounding_box for this model is not compound") 

1524 

1525 @bounding_box.deleter 

1526 def bounding_box(self): 

1527 self._user_bounding_box = None 

1528 

1529 @property 

1530 def has_user_bounding_box(self): 

1531 """ 

1532 A flag indicating whether or not a custom bounding_box has been 

1533 assigned to this model by a user, via assignment to 

1534 ``model.bounding_box``. 

1535 """ 

1536 return self._user_bounding_box is not None

1538 @property 

1539 def cov_matrix(self): 

1540 """ 

1541 Fitter should set covariance matrix, if available. 

1542 """ 

1543 return self._cov_matrix 

1544 

1545 @cov_matrix.setter 

1546 def cov_matrix(self, cov): 

1547 self._cov_matrix = cov 

1548 

1549 unfix_untied_params = [ 

1550 p 

1551 for p in self.param_names 

1552 if (self.fixed[p] is False) and (self.tied[p] is False) 

1553 ] 

1554 if type(cov) == list: # model set 

1555 param_stds = [] 

1556 for c in cov: 

1557 param_stds.append( 

1558 [np.sqrt(x) if x > 0 else None for x in np.diag(c.cov_matrix)] 

1559 ) 

1560 for p, param_name in enumerate(unfix_untied_params): 

1561 par = getattr(self, param_name) 

1562 par.std = [item[p] for item in param_stds] 

1563 setattr(self, param_name, par) 

1564 else: 

1565 param_stds = [ 

1566 np.sqrt(x) if x > 0 else None for x in np.diag(cov.cov_matrix) 

1567 ] 

1568 for param_name in unfix_untied_params: 

1569 par = getattr(self, param_name) 

1570 par.std = param_stds.pop(0) 

1571 setattr(self, param_name, par) 

1572

1595 

1596 def without_units_for_data(self, **kwargs): 

1597 """ 

1598 Return an instance of the model for which the parameter values have 

1599 been converted to the right units for the data, then the units have 

1600 been stripped away. 

1601 

1602 The input and output Quantity objects should be given as keyword 

1603 arguments. 

1604 

1605 Notes 

1606 ----- 

1607 This method is needed in order to be able to fit models with units in 

1608 the parameters, since we need to temporarily strip away the units from 

1609 the model during the fitting (which might be done by e.g. scipy 

1610 functions). 

1611 

1612 The units that the parameters should be converted to are not 

1613 necessarily the units of the input data, but are derived from them. 

1614 Model subclasses that want fitting to work in the presence of 

1615 quantities need to define a ``_parameter_units_for_data_units`` method 

1616 that takes the input and output units (as two dictionaries) and 

1617 returns a dictionary giving the target units for each parameter. 

1618 

1619 """ 

1620 model = self.copy() 

1621 

1622 inputs_unit = { 

1623 inp: getattr(kwargs[inp], "unit", dimensionless_unscaled) 

1624 for inp in self.inputs 

1625 if kwargs[inp] is not None 

1626 } 

1627 

1628 outputs_unit = { 

1629 out: getattr(kwargs[out], "unit", dimensionless_unscaled) 

1630 for out in self.outputs 

1631 if kwargs[out] is not None 

1632 } 

1633 parameter_units = self._parameter_units_for_data_units( 

1634 inputs_unit, outputs_unit 

1635 ) 

1636 for name, unit in parameter_units.items(): 

1637 parameter = getattr(model, name) 

1638 if parameter.unit is not None: 

1639 parameter.value = parameter.quantity.to(unit).value 

1640 parameter._set_unit(None, force=True) 

1641 

1642 if isinstance(model, CompoundModel): 

1643 model.strip_units_from_tree() 

1644 

1645 return model 

1646 

1647 def output_units(self, **kwargs): 

1648 """ 

1649 Return a dictionary of output units for this model given a dictionary 

1650 of fitting inputs and outputs. 

1651 

1652 The input and output Quantity objects should be given as keyword 

1653 arguments. 

1654 

1655 Notes 

1656 ----- 

1657 This method is needed in order to be able to fit models with units in 

1658 the parameters, since we need to temporarily strip away the units from 

1659 the model during the fitting (which might be done by e.g. scipy 

1660 functions). 

1661 

1662 This method will force extra model evaluations, which maybe computationally 

1663 expensive. To avoid this, one can add a return_units property to the model, 

1664 see :ref:`astropy:models_return_units`. 

1665 """ 

1666 units = self.return_units 

1667 

1668 if units is None or units == {}: 

1669 inputs = {inp: kwargs[inp] for inp in self.inputs} 

1670 

1671 values = self(**inputs) 

1672 if self.n_outputs == 1: 

1673 values = (values,) 

1674 

1675 units = { 

1676 out: getattr(values[index], "unit", dimensionless_unscaled) 

1677 for index, out in enumerate(self.outputs) 

1678 } 

1679 

1680 return units 

1681 

1682 def strip_units_from_tree(self): 

1683 for item in self._leaflist: 

1684 for parname in item.param_names: 

1685 par = getattr(item, parname) 

1686 par._set_unit(None, force=True) 

1687 

1688 def with_units_from_data(self, **kwargs): 

1689 """ 

1690 Return an instance of the model which has units for which the parameter 

1691 values are compatible with the data units specified. 

1692 

1693 The input and output Quantity objects should be given as keyword 

1694 arguments. 

1695 

1696 Notes 

1697 ----- 

1698 This method is needed in order to be able to fit models with units in 

1699 the parameters, since we need to temporarily strip away the units from 

1700 the model during the fitting (which might be done by e.g. scipy 

1701 functions). 

1702 

1703 The units that the parameters will gain are not necessarily the units 

1704 of the input data, but are derived from them. Model subclasses that 

1705 want fitting to work in the presence of quantities need to define a 

1706 ``_parameter_units_for_data_units`` method that takes the input and output 

1707 units (as two dictionaries) and returns a dictionary giving the target 

1708 units for each parameter. 

1709 """ 

1710 model = self.copy() 

1711 inputs_unit = { 

1712 inp: getattr(kwargs[inp], "unit", dimensionless_unscaled) 

1713 for inp in self.inputs 

1714 if kwargs[inp] is not None 

1715 } 

1716 

1717 outputs_unit = { 

1718 out: getattr(kwargs[out], "unit", dimensionless_unscaled) 

1719 for out in self.outputs 

1720 if kwargs[out] is not None 

1721 } 

1722 

1723 parameter_units = self._parameter_units_for_data_units( 

1724 inputs_unit, outputs_unit 

1725 ) 

1726 

1727 # We are adding units to parameters that already have a value, but we 

1728 # don't want to convert the parameter, just add the unit directly, 

1729 # hence the call to ``_set_unit``. 

1730 for name, unit in parameter_units.items(): 

1731 parameter = getattr(model, name) 

1732 parameter._set_unit(unit, force=True) 

1733 

1734 return model 

1735 

1736 @property 

1737 def _has_units(self): 

1738 # Returns True if any of the parameters have units 

1739 return any(getattr(self, param).unit is not None for param in self.param_names) 

1740 

1741 @property 

1742 def _supports_unit_fitting(self): 

1743 # If the model has a ``_parameter_units_for_data_units`` method, this 

1744 # indicates that we have enough information to strip the units away 

1745 # and add them back after fitting, when fitting quantities 

1746 return hasattr(self, "_parameter_units_for_data_units")

1748 @abc.abstractmethod 

1749 def evaluate(self, *args, **kwargs): 

1750 """Evaluate the model on some input variables.""" 

1751 

1752 def sum_of_implicit_terms(self, *args, **kwargs): 

1753 """ 

1754 Evaluate the sum of any implicit model terms on some input variables. 

1755 This includes any fixed terms used in evaluating a linear model that 

1756 do not have corresponding parameters exposed to the user. The 

1757 prototypical case is `astropy.modeling.functional_models.Shift`, which 

1758 corresponds to a function y = a + bx, where b=1 is intrinsically fixed 

1759 by the type of model, such that sum_of_implicit_terms(x) == x. This 

1760 method is needed by linear fitters to correct the dependent variable 

1761 for the implicit term(s) when solving for the remaining terms 

1762 (ie. a = y - bx). 

1763 """ 

1764 

1765 def render(self, out=None, coords=None): 

1766 """ 

1767 Evaluate a model at fixed positions, respecting the ``bounding_box``. 

1768 

1769 The key difference relative to evaluating the model directly is that 

1770 this method is limited to a bounding box if the `Model.bounding_box` 

1771 attribute is set. 

1772 

1773 Parameters 

1774 ---------- 

1775 out : `numpy.ndarray`, optional 

1776 An array that the evaluated model will be added to. If this is not 

1777 given (or given as ``None``), a new array will be created. 

1778 coords : array-like, optional 

1779 An array to be used to translate from the model's input coordinates 

1780 to the ``out`` array. It should have the property that 

1781 ``self(coords)`` yields the same shape as ``out``. If ``out`` is 

1782 not specified, ``coords`` will be used to determine the shape of 

1783 the returned array. If this is not provided (or None), the model 

1784 will be evaluated on a grid determined by `Model.bounding_box`. 

1785 

1786 Returns 

1787 ------- 

1788 out : `numpy.ndarray` 

1789 The model added to ``out`` if ``out`` is not ``None``, or else a 

1790 new array from evaluating the model over ``coords``. 

1791 If ``out`` and ``coords`` are both `None`, the returned array is 

1792 limited to the `Model.bounding_box` limits. If 

1793 `Model.bounding_box` is `None`, ``arr`` or ``coords`` must be 

1794 passed. 

1795 

1796 Raises 

1797 ------ 

1798 ValueError 

1799 If ``coords`` are not given and the the `Model.bounding_box` of 

1800 this model is not set. 

1801 

1802 Examples 

1803 -------- 

1804 :ref:`astropy:bounding-boxes` 

1805 """ 

1806 try: 

1807 bbox = self.bounding_box 

1808 except NotImplementedError: 

1809 bbox = None 

1810 

1811 if isinstance(bbox, ModelBoundingBox): 

1812 bbox = bbox.bounding_box() 

1813 

1814 ndim = self.n_inputs 

1815 

1816 if (coords is None) and (out is None) and (bbox is None): 

1817 raise ValueError("If no bounding_box is set, coords or out must be input.") 

1818 

1819 # for consistent indexing 

1820 if ndim == 1: 

1821 if coords is not None: 

1822 coords = [coords] 

1823 if bbox is not None: 

1824 bbox = [bbox] 

1825 

1826 if coords is not None: 

1827 coords = np.asanyarray(coords, dtype=float) 

1828 # Check dimensions match out and model 

1829 assert len(coords) == ndim 

1830 if out is not None: 

1831 if coords[0].shape != out.shape: 

1832 raise ValueError("inconsistent shape of the output.") 

1833 else: 

1834 out = np.zeros(coords[0].shape) 

1835 

1836 if out is not None: 

1837 out = np.asanyarray(out) 

1838 if out.ndim != ndim: 

1839 raise ValueError( 

1840 "the array and model must have the same number of dimensions." 

1841 ) 

1842 

1843 if bbox is not None: 

1844 # Assures position is at center pixel, 

1845 # important when using add_array. 

1846 pd = ( 

1847 np.array([(np.mean(bb), np.ceil((bb[1] - bb[0]) / 2)) for bb in bbox]) 

1848 .astype(int) 

1849 .T 

1850 ) 

1851 pos, delta = pd 

1852 

1853 if coords is not None: 

1854 sub_shape = tuple(delta * 2 + 1) 

1855 sub_coords = np.array( 

1856 [extract_array(c, sub_shape, pos) for c in coords] 

1857 ) 

1858 else: 

1859 limits = [slice(p - d, p + d + 1, 1) for p, d in pd.T] 

1860 sub_coords = np.mgrid[limits] 

1861 

1862 sub_coords = sub_coords[::-1] 

1863 

1864 if out is None: 

1865 out = self(*sub_coords) 

1866 else: 

1867 try: 

1868 out = add_array(out, self(*sub_coords), pos) 

1869 except ValueError: 

1870 raise ValueError( 

1871 "The `bounding_box` is larger than the input out in " 

1872 "one or more dimensions. Set " 

1873 "`model.bounding_box = None`." 

1874 ) 

1875 else: 

1876 if coords is None: 

1877 im_shape = out.shape 

1878 limits = [slice(i) for i in im_shape] 

1879 coords = np.mgrid[limits] 

1880 

1881 coords = coords[::-1] 

1882 

1883 out += self(*coords) 

1884 

1885 return out 

1886 

1887 @property 

1888 def input_units(self): 

1889 """ 

1890 This property is used to indicate what units or sets of units the 

1891 evaluate method expects, and returns a dictionary mapping inputs to 

1892 units (or `None` if any units are accepted). 

1893 

1894 Model sub-classes can also use function annotations in evaluate to 

1895 indicate valid input units, in which case this property should 

1896 not be overridden since it will return the input units based on the 

1897 annotations. 

1898 """ 

1899 if hasattr(self, "_input_units"): 

1900 return self._input_units 

1901 elif hasattr(self.evaluate, "__annotations__"): 

1902 annotations = self.evaluate.__annotations__.copy() 

1903 annotations.pop("return", None) 

1904 if annotations: 

1905 # If there are not annotations for all inputs this will error. 

1906 return {name: annotations[name] for name in self.inputs} 

1907 else: 

1908 # None means any unit is accepted 

1909 return None 

1910 

1911 @property 

1912 def return_units(self): 

1913 """ 

1914 This property is used to indicate what units or sets of units the 

1915 output of evaluate should be in, and returns a dictionary mapping 

1916 outputs to units (or `None` if any units are accepted). 

1917 

1918 Model sub-classes can also use function annotations in evaluate to 

1919 indicate valid output units, in which case this property should not be 

1920 overridden since it will return the return units based on the 

1921 annotations. 

1922 """ 

1923 if hasattr(self, "_return_units"): 

1924 return self._return_units 

1925 elif hasattr(self.evaluate, "__annotations__"): 

1926 return self.evaluate.__annotations__.get("return", None) 

1927 else: 

1928 # None means any unit is accepted 

1929 return None 

1930 

1931 def _prepare_inputs_single_model(self, params, inputs, **kwargs): 

1932 broadcasts = [] 

1933 for idx, _input in enumerate(inputs): 

1934 input_shape = _input.shape 

1935 

1936 # Ensure that array scalars are always upgrade to 1-D arrays for the 

1937 # sake of consistency with how parameters work. They will be cast back 

1938 # to scalars at the end 

1939 if not input_shape: 

1940 inputs[idx] = _input.reshape((1,)) 

1941 

1942 if not params: 

1943 max_broadcast = input_shape 

1944 else: 

1945 max_broadcast = () 

1946 

1947 for param in params: 

1948 try: 

1949 if self.standard_broadcasting: 

1950 broadcast = check_broadcast(input_shape, param.shape) 

1951 else: 

1952 broadcast = input_shape 

1953 except IncompatibleShapeError: 

1954 raise ValueError( 

1955 f"self input argument {self.inputs[idx]!r} of shape" 

1956 f" {input_shape!r} cannot be broadcast with parameter" 

1957 f" {param.name!r} of shape {param.shape!r}." 

1958 ) 

1959 

1960 if len(broadcast) > len(max_broadcast): 

1961 max_broadcast = broadcast 

1962 elif len(broadcast) == len(max_broadcast): 

1963 max_broadcast = max(max_broadcast, broadcast) 

1964 

1965 broadcasts.append(max_broadcast) 

1966 

1967 if self.n_outputs > self.n_inputs: 

1968 extra_outputs = self.n_outputs - self.n_inputs 

1969 if not broadcasts: 

1970 # If there were no inputs then the broadcasts list is empty 

1971 # just add a None since there is no broadcasting of outputs and 

1972 # inputs necessary (see _prepare_outputs_single_self) 

1973 broadcasts.append(None) 

1974 broadcasts.extend([broadcasts[0]] * extra_outputs) 

1975 

1976 return inputs, (broadcasts,) 

1977 

1978 @staticmethod 

1979 def _remove_axes_from_shape(shape, axis): 

1980 """ 

1981 Given a shape tuple as the first input, construct a new one by removing 

1982 that particular axis from the shape and all preceding axes. Negative axis 

1983 numbers are permittted, where the axis is relative to the last axis. 

1984 """ 

1985 if len(shape) == 0: 

1986 return shape 

1987 if axis < 0: 

1988 axis = len(shape) + axis 

1989 return shape[:axis] + shape[axis + 1 :] 

1990 if axis >= len(shape): 

1991 axis = len(shape) - 1 

1992 shape = shape[axis + 1 :] 

1993 return shape 

1994 

1995 def _prepare_inputs_model_set(self, params, inputs, model_set_axis_input, **kwargs): 

1996 reshaped = [] 

1997 pivots = [] 

1998 

1999 model_set_axis_param = self.model_set_axis # needed to reshape param 

2000 for idx, _input in enumerate(inputs): 

2001 max_param_shape = () 

2002 if self._n_models > 1 and model_set_axis_input is not False: 

2003 # Use the shape of the input *excluding* the model axis 

2004 input_shape = ( 

2005 _input.shape[:model_set_axis_input] 

2006 + _input.shape[model_set_axis_input + 1 :] 

2007 ) 

2008 else: 

2009 input_shape = _input.shape 

2010 

2011 for param in params: 

2012 try: 

2013 check_broadcast( 

2014 input_shape, 

2015 self._remove_axes_from_shape(param.shape, model_set_axis_param), 

2016 ) 

2017 except IncompatibleShapeError: 

2018 raise ValueError( 

2019 f"Model input argument {self.inputs[idx]!r} of shape" 

2020 f" {input_shape!r} " 

2021 f"cannot be broadcast with parameter {param.name!r} of shape " 

2022 f"{self._remove_axes_from_shape(param.shape, model_set_axis_param)!r}." 

2023 ) 

2024 

2025 if len(param.shape) - 1 > len(max_param_shape): 

2026 max_param_shape = self._remove_axes_from_shape( 

2027 param.shape, model_set_axis_param 

2028 ) 

2029 

2030 # We've now determined that, excluding the model_set_axis, the 

2031 # input can broadcast with all the parameters 

2032 input_ndim = len(input_shape) 

2033 if model_set_axis_input is False: 

2034 if len(max_param_shape) > input_ndim: 

2035 # Just needs to prepend new axes to the input 

2036 n_new_axes = 1 + len(max_param_shape) - input_ndim 

2037 new_axes = (1,) * n_new_axes 

2038 new_shape = new_axes + _input.shape 

2039 pivot = model_set_axis_param 

2040 else: 

2041 pivot = input_ndim - len(max_param_shape) 

2042 new_shape = _input.shape[:pivot] + (1,) + _input.shape[pivot:] 

2043 new_input = _input.reshape(new_shape) 

2044 else: 

2045 if len(max_param_shape) >= input_ndim: 

2046 n_new_axes = len(max_param_shape) - input_ndim 

2047 pivot = self.model_set_axis 

2048 new_axes = (1,) * n_new_axes 

2049 new_shape = ( 

2050 _input.shape[: pivot + 1] + new_axes + _input.shape[pivot + 1 :] 

2051 ) 

2052 new_input = _input.reshape(new_shape) 

2053 else: 

2054 pivot = _input.ndim - len(max_param_shape) - 1 

2055 new_input = np.rollaxis(_input, model_set_axis_input, pivot + 1) 

2056 pivots.append(pivot) 

2057 reshaped.append(new_input) 

2058 

2059 if self.n_inputs < self.n_outputs: 

2060 pivots.extend([model_set_axis_input] * (self.n_outputs - self.n_inputs)) 

2061 

2062 return reshaped, (pivots,) 

2063 

2064 def prepare_inputs( 

2065 self, *inputs, model_set_axis=None, equivalencies=None, **kwargs 

2066 ): 

2067 """ 

2068 This method is used in `~astropy.modeling.Model.__call__` to ensure 

2069 that all the inputs to the model can be broadcast into compatible 

2070 shapes (if one or both of them are input as arrays), particularly if 

2071 there are more than one parameter sets. This also makes sure that (if 

2072 applicable) the units of the input will be compatible with the evaluate 

2073 method. 

2074 """ 

2075 # When we instantiate the model class, we make sure that __call__ can 

2076 # take the following two keyword arguments: model_set_axis and 

2077 # equivalencies. 

2078 if model_set_axis is None: 

2079 # By default the model_set_axis for the input is assumed to be the 

2080 # same as that for the parameters the model was defined with 

2081 # TODO: Ensure that negative model_set_axis arguments are respected 

2082 model_set_axis = self.model_set_axis 

2083 

2084 params = [getattr(self, name) for name in self.param_names] 

2085 inputs = [np.asanyarray(_input, dtype=float) for _input in inputs] 

2086 

2087 self._validate_input_shapes(inputs, self.inputs, model_set_axis) 

2088 

2089 inputs_map = kwargs.get("inputs_map", None) 

2090 

2091 inputs = self._validate_input_units(inputs, equivalencies, inputs_map) 

2092 

2093 # The input formatting required for single models versus a multiple 

2094 # model set are different enough that they've been split into separate 

2095 # subroutines 

2096 if self._n_models == 1: 

2097 return self._prepare_inputs_single_model(params, inputs, **kwargs) 

2098 else: 

2099 return self._prepare_inputs_model_set( 

2100 params, inputs, model_set_axis, **kwargs 

2101 ) 

2102 

2103 def _validate_input_units(self, inputs, equivalencies=None, inputs_map=None): 

2104 inputs = list(inputs) 

2105 name = self.name or self.__class__.__name__ 

2106 # Check that the units are correct, if applicable 

2107 

2108 if self.input_units is not None: 

2109 # If a leaflist is provided that means this is in the context of 

2110 # a compound model and it is necessary to create the appropriate 

2111 # alias for the input coordinate name for the equivalencies dict 

2112 if inputs_map: 

2113 edict = {} 

2114 for mod, mapping in inputs_map: 

2115 if self is mod: 

2116 edict[mapping[0]] = equivalencies[mapping[1]] 

2117 else: 

2118 edict = equivalencies 

2119 # We combine any instance-level input equivalencies with user 

2120 # specified ones at call-time. 

2121 input_units_equivalencies = _combine_equivalency_dict( 

2122 self.inputs, edict, self.input_units_equivalencies 

2123 ) 

2124 

2125 # We now iterate over the different inputs and make sure that their 

2126 # units are consistent with those specified in input_units. 

2127 for i in range(len(inputs)): 

2128 input_name = self.inputs[i] 

2129 input_unit = self.input_units.get(input_name, None) 

2130 

2131 if input_unit is None: 

2132 continue 

2133 

2134 if isinstance(inputs[i], Quantity): 

2135 # We check for consistency of the units with input_units, 

2136 # taking into account any equivalencies 

2137 

2138 if inputs[i].unit.is_equivalent( 

2139 input_unit, equivalencies=input_units_equivalencies[input_name] 

2140 ): 

2141 # If equivalencies have been specified, we need to 

2142 # convert the input to the input units - this is 

2143 # because some equivalencies are non-linear, and 

2144 # we need to be sure that we evaluate the model in 

2145 # its own frame of reference. If input_units_strict 

2146 # is set, we also need to convert to the input units. 

2147 if ( 

2148 len(input_units_equivalencies) > 0 

2149 or self.input_units_strict[input_name] 

2150 ): 

2151 inputs[i] = inputs[i].to( 

2152 input_unit, 

2153 equivalencies=input_units_equivalencies[input_name], 

2154 ) 

2155 

2156 else: 

2157 # We consider the following two cases separately so as 

2158 # to be able to raise more appropriate/nicer exceptions 

2159 

2160 if input_unit is dimensionless_unscaled: 

2161 raise UnitsError( 

2162 f"{name}: Units of input '{self.inputs[i]}', " 

2163 f"{inputs[i].unit} ({inputs[i].unit.physical_type})," 

2164 "could not be converted to " 

2165 "required dimensionless " 

2166 "input" 

2167 ) 

2168 else: 

2169 raise UnitsError( 

2170 f"{name}: Units of input '{self.inputs[i]}', " 

2171 f"{inputs[i].unit} ({inputs[i].unit.physical_type})," 

2172 " could not be " 

2173 "converted to required input" 

2174 f" units of {input_unit} ({input_unit.physical_type})" 

2175 ) 

2176 else: 

2177 # If we allow dimensionless input, we add the units to the 

2178 # input values without conversion, otherwise we raise an 

2179 # exception. 

2180 

2181 if ( 

2182 not self.input_units_allow_dimensionless[input_name] 

2183 and input_unit is not dimensionless_unscaled 

2184 and input_unit is not None 

2185 ): 

2186 if np.any(inputs[i] != 0): 

2187 raise UnitsError( 

2188 f"{name}: Units of input '{self.inputs[i]}'," 

2189 " (dimensionless), could not be converted to required " 

2190 f"input units of {input_unit} " 

2191 f"({input_unit.physical_type})" 

2192 ) 

2193 return inputs 

2194 

2195 def _process_output_units(self, inputs, outputs): 

2196 inputs_are_quantity = any(isinstance(i, Quantity) for i in inputs) 

2197 if self.return_units and inputs_are_quantity: 

2198 # We allow a non-iterable unit only if there is one output 

2199 if self.n_outputs == 1 and not isiterable(self.return_units): 

2200 return_units = {self.outputs[0]: self.return_units} 

2201 else: 

2202 return_units = self.return_units 

2203 

2204 outputs = tuple( 

2205 Quantity(out, return_units.get(out_name, None), subok=True) 

2206 for out, out_name in zip(outputs, self.outputs) 

2207 ) 

2208 return outputs 

2209 

2210 @staticmethod 

2211 def _prepare_output_single_model(output, broadcast_shape): 

2212 if broadcast_shape is not None: 

2213 if not broadcast_shape: 

2214 return output.item() 

2215 else: 

2216 try: 

2217 return output.reshape(broadcast_shape) 

2218 except ValueError: 

2219 try: 

2220 return output.item() 

2221 except ValueError: 

2222 return output 

2223 

2224 return output 

2225 

2226 def _prepare_outputs_single_model(self, outputs, broadcasted_shapes): 

2227 outputs = list(outputs) 

2228 for idx, output in enumerate(outputs): 

2229 try: 

2230 broadcast_shape = check_broadcast(*broadcasted_shapes[0]) 

2231 except (IndexError, TypeError): 

2232 broadcast_shape = broadcasted_shapes[0][idx] 

2233 

2234 outputs[idx] = self._prepare_output_single_model(output, broadcast_shape) 

2235 

2236 return tuple(outputs) 

2237 

2238 def _prepare_outputs_model_set(self, outputs, broadcasted_shapes, model_set_axis): 

2239 pivots = broadcasted_shapes[0] 

2240 # If model_set_axis = False was passed then use 

2241 # self._model_set_axis to format the output. 

2242 if model_set_axis is None or model_set_axis is False: 

2243 model_set_axis = self.model_set_axis 

2244 outputs = list(outputs) 

2245 for idx, output in enumerate(outputs): 

2246 pivot = pivots[idx] 

2247 if pivot < output.ndim and pivot != model_set_axis: 

2248 outputs[idx] = np.rollaxis(output, pivot, model_set_axis) 

2249 return tuple(outputs) 

2250 

2251 def prepare_outputs(self, broadcasted_shapes, *outputs, **kwargs): 

2252 model_set_axis = kwargs.get("model_set_axis", None) 

2253 

2254 if len(self) == 1: 

2255 return self._prepare_outputs_single_model(outputs, broadcasted_shapes) 

2256 else: 

2257 return self._prepare_outputs_model_set( 

2258 outputs, broadcasted_shapes, model_set_axis 

2259 )

2267 """ 

2268 return copy.deepcopy(self)

2272 Return a deep copy of this model.

2275 return self.copy()

2280 Return a copy of this model with a new name.
